js
Class JsApplet

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          java.awt.Panel
              java.applet.Applet
                  js.JsApplet
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible
public abstract class JsApplet
extends java.applet.Applet

A normal class extended to develop JS applets (also called JsApplets) which can be re-compiled by third-party JS re-compilers into JavaScript applications (also called scriptlets) as well as loaded and run directly with JS Simulation (packed as sim.jar) as normal Java applets.

Developers are only expected to extend this class to create JS applets and override its abstract method onReady() to make entry points for them. The members of this class, except for this abstract method and start(), are all internal. The superclass java.applet is obviously internal. Any use, from the entry points, of the internal members shall cause re-compilation failure.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org
See Also:
Serialized Form
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must first load the subclasses of this one which have concrete methods overriding onReady(), replacing the naming references to this class with that to the class com.javajavascript.emu.scriptlet, which is also normal, then resolve those subclasses and start re-compilation processes from the static onLoad(JsApplet) method of that class.

init

public final void init()

Internally initializes this Java applet.

This method is internal and can only be called by JRE plugin at browser client.

Overrides:

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must report error on the invocation to an internal method.

start

public final void start()

Starts this Java applet.

This method is normal but only expected to be called by JRE plugin at browser client.

Overrides:
start in class java.applet.Applet
Since:
1.0

onReady

public abstract void onReady()

The entry point of the extended JS applet.

The method is normal but not expected to be called. A concrete method overriding this one is also normal, so we must write "normal" Java statements to start the applet and re-compilation shall start its processing from there.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
A Re-compiler must start the process from the concrete overriding method in an extended JS applet and make an explicit invocation of it.

stop

public final void stop()

Internally stops this Java applet.

This method is internal and can only be called by JRE plugin at browser client.

Overrides:

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must report error on the invocation to an internal method.
